  "article_text": [
    "let @xmath3 be the moduli space of stable @xmath4-pointed rational curves .",
    "the one - dimensional boundary strata of the moduli space , i.e. , the irreducible components of the locus parameterizing rational curves with at least @xmath5 components are often called _",
    "@xmath0-curves_. a long standing open question @xcite ( known as the @xmath0-conjecture ) is whether the mori cone of curves @xmath6 is generated by @xmath0-curves .",
    "gibney , keel and morrison @xcite proved that the @xmath0-conjecture for all @xmath4 implies that the same is true for the moduli spaces @xmath7 of stable , genus @xmath8 , @xmath4-pointed curves , namely , that the mori cone @xmath9 is generated by one - dimensional boundary strata ( thus , giving an explicit description of the ample cone of @xmath7 ) .",
    "keel and m^c^kernan @xcite proved the @xmath0-conjecture for @xmath10 and proved that a hypothetical counterexample to the @xmath0-conjecture must come from _ rigid curves _ intersecting the interior @xmath11 ( see thm .",
    "[ km theorem ] for a precise statement ) .",
    "the notion of rigidity in the keel - m^c^kernan result is a very strong one :    [ rigid def ] let @xmath12 be a curve on a variety @xmath13 .",
    "we say that @xmath12 _ moves _ on @xmath13 if there is a flat family of curves @xmath14 over a curve germ @xmath15 , with a map @xmath16 such that @xmath17 and @xmath18 ( set - theoretically ) .",
    "we  say that @xmath12 is _ rigid _ on @xmath13 if @xmath12 does not move .    we observe that if the curve @xmath12 is an irreducible component of the exceptional locus of a regular map @xmath19 ( for some @xmath20 ) , then @xmath12 is rigid on @xmath13 in the sense of def .",
    "[ rigid def ] .",
    "indeed , this is an immediate application of mumford s rigidity lemma @xcite . on @xmath3 , the natural maps to consider are products of forgetful maps . in sections",
    "[ blow - ups section ] , [ hypergraph section ] , and [ hessesection ] we discuss a construction , which we call the _ hypergraph construction_. the basic idea is that @xmath3 is covered by arbitrary blow - ups of @xmath21 in @xmath4 points ( as long as these points do not belong to a ( possibly reducible ) conic ) .",
    "the curves that we consider are @xmath22-curves in these blow - ups .",
    "the hypergraph construction uses a rigid configuration of @xmath4 points to construct interesting curves and surfaces in @xmath3 , that intersect the interior @xmath11 , and are contracted by some natural products of forgetful maps .",
    "it is in general difficult to decide when the exceptional locus of such a map has a @xmath23-dimensional irreducible component .",
    "we have been able to prove this by an ad - hoc argument in one example .",
    "namely , one starts with the @xmath24 hesse configuration of @xmath25 inflection points of a non - singular plane cubic and @xmath26 lines connecting them pairwise . applying our hypergraph construction to the configuration projectively dual to the hesse configuration ,",
    "one gets in this way a rigid curve on @xmath27 .",
    "( this construction appeared first in the authors preprint @xcite . )    the notion of rigidity in def .",
    "[ rigid def ] is much stronger than the one usually used for maps @xcite : a map @xmath28 is called rigid if any family of maps containing @xmath29 is isotrivial . here",
    "a family of maps is a proper flat family of curves @xmath14 with reduced fibers over a curve germ @xmath15 , with a map @xmath30 such that @xmath31 .",
    "the family of maps is isotrivial if ( after shrinking @xmath32 ) it is isomorphic over @xmath32 to the constant family @xmath33 , @xmath34 .",
    "if @xmath12 is a rigid curve on @xmath13 , the embedding map @xmath28 is a rigid map , but the converse does not hold in general .",
    "indeed , consider a family of quartic plane curves specializing to a double conic . if @xmath12 denotes the reduced conic on the total space @xmath35 of the family ,",
    "then clearly @xmath12 is not a rigid curve on @xmath35 , but the embedding map @xmath36 is rigid .",
    "rigid maps @xmath37 were recently constructed by chen  @xcite using results of mcmullen @xcite and mller @xcite on teichmller curves .",
    "an amazing feature of chen s curves is that their union is dense in @xmath3 for every @xmath38 .",
    "it seems to be a difficult problem to decide whether these curves are rigid in the sense of def .",
    "[ rigid def ] .    in section  [ dej - k ] we present a different construction of rigid maps inspired by discussions with j. kollr and j. de jong from a few years ago .",
    "it uses rigid configurations of lines and conics in the plane .",
    "we call this the `` two conics '' construction .",
    "we give an explicit example of such a curve in section [ break of 2-conics curve ] using the configuration of grnbaum  @xcite of @xmath25 lines in the plane representing the golden ratio .",
    "we then proceed to show that all the rigid curves ( and images of rigid maps ) that we found can be decomposed into sums of @xmath0-curves .",
    "this is easy for curves found in @xcite : these curves lie in the symmetric mori cone @xmath39 and their classes are easily seen to be sums of @xmath0-curves .",
    "curves obtained using hypergraph and `` two conics '' constructions are highly asymmetric , and it is hard to see how their classes can break into sums of @xmath0-curves .",
    "however , we have found a way to break not just the class of the curve but the curve itself using a simple idea that we call an `` arithmetic break '' .",
    "the above - mentioned result of keel and m^c^kernan says , roughly , that if a curve on @xmath40 moves in a one - parameter family then it breaks ( one of the fibers is reducible ) .",
    "we  remark that even a rigid curve @xmath12 moves in an arithmetic sense .",
    "namely , its field of definition @xmath41 is a field of algebraic numbers .",
    "let @xmath42 be the integral closure of @xmath43 .",
    "then @xmath12 has an integral model @xmath44 over @xmath45 , which is a subscheme in the @xmath46-moduli scheme @xmath47 .",
    "we observe that in all our examples , one of the fibers of @xmath48 is reducible .",
    "we further analyze irreducible components of this fiber ( defined over the corresponding finite field ) , and show that these components move and break , and in fact break down to effective linear combinations of @xmath0-curves , thus showing that the class of @xmath12 is also an effective sum of @xmath0-curves . here",
    "we use a well - known fact that @xmath49 is characteristic - independent ( this follows from the description of @xmath50 as a blow - up - kapranov @xcite , keel @xcite or knudsen @xcite ) .",
    "this raises an interesting question :    is it possible to construct a rigid curve on @xmath40 that intersects the interior such that all its reductions modulo @xmath2 are irreducible ?    note that rigidity is important here : it is possible to construct an embedding @xmath51 that intersects the interior , even though we know only one example , which arises from the grnbaum configuration ( see section [ rigid matroids ] ) using the hypergraph construction .",
    "however , the generic fiber of such a map is not a rigid curve .    in section",
    "[ km argument ] , for the reader s convenience we reproduce , with the authors permission , the keel - m^c^kernan argument ( thm .",
    "[ km theorem ] does not appear in its current form in @xcite ) . in section [ blow - ups section ]",
    "we give a general construction of surfaces in @xmath3 , that intersect the interior @xmath11 , starting with a configuration of points in @xmath52 .",
    "section [ hypergraph section ] explains the hypergraph construction . in section [ hessesection ]",
    "we consider a specific example coming from the hesse configuration .",
    "we find a curve on @xmath27 which is an irreducible component of the exceptional locus of a generically finite map @xmath53 . in section [ dej - k ]",
    "we present the  two conics construction \" . in section [ break of hypergraph curve ]",
    "we explain how the hesse curve breaks into several components in positive characteristic .",
    "this allows us to write the class of the curve as a sum of @xmath0-curves . in section [ break of 2-conics curve ]",
    "we do the same for a curve obtained via the two - conic construction .",
    "we work over an algebraically closed field @xmath54 ( in sections [ km argument ] , [ blow - ups section ] , [ hypergraph section ] , [ hessesection ] and [ dej - k ] ) , unless we specify otherwise ( such as in sections [ break of hypergraph curve ] , [ break of 2-conics curve ] and [ tangent ] ) .",
    "the first author was partially supported by the nsf grant dms-1001157 .",
    "the second author was partially supported by the nsf grants dms-0701191 , dms-1001344 , and sloan fellowship .",
    "parts of this paper were written while the first author was visiting the max - planck institute in bonn , germany .",
    "the authors are grateful to the referee for useful suggestions on how to improve the exposition of the article .",

    "concretely , the vector space @xmath57 ( of linear forms that vanish on @xmath46 ) should be generated by supporting hyperplanes for @xmath56 .",
    "@xcite[km theorem ] suppose that the mori cone @xmath6 has an extremal ray which is an edge and is generated by a curve @xmath58 such that @xmath59 .",
    "then @xmath12 is rigid .    assuming that the mori cone @xmath6 is finitely generated , and moreover each extremal ray is generated by a curve , then if @xmath12 is a curve that generates an extremal ray of @xmath6 , then either @xmath12 intersects the interior @xmath11 and by theorem [ km theorem ] it must be rigid , or @xmath12 is contained in a boundary component . in the latter case , as @xmath60 it follows that @xmath12 is obtained from a curve in @xmath61 for some @xmath62 , by attaching a fixed curve with fixed markings .",
    "moreover , @xmath12 itself generates an extremal ray of @xmath63 .",
    "it follows that either @xmath12 is an @xmath0-curve , or eventually one obtains a counterexample to the @xmath0-conjecture from a rigid curve @xmath64 that intersects the interior @xmath11 .",
    "for completeness , note that @xmath0-curves do generate extremal rays of @xmath6 .",
    "this is easily seen by induction , using ( [ product ] ) .",

    ". then @xmath184 , for the forgetful map @xmath185 .",
    "first suppose that @xmath186 .",
    "consider three cases .",
    "if no three out of the four points @xmath187 lie on a line then @xmath188 is given by the pencil of conics through @xmath187 .",
    "if @xmath189 lie on a line that does not contain @xmath190 then @xmath191 is a projection from @xmath190 .",
    "finally , if all points lie on a line then @xmath192 is a map to a point ( given by the cross - ratio of @xmath187 on the line they span ) .",
    "note that in all cases @xmath0 is regular on @xmath193 .",
    "the product of all forgetful maps @xmath194 over all @xmath195-element subsets is a closed embedding ( see e.g.  ( * ? ? ?",
    "it follows that is regular .",
    "now suppose that there is no conic passing through all points .",
    "the argument above shows that @xmath0 restricted to each exceptional divisor @xmath196 is a closed immersion .",
    "indeed , there always exist three points @xmath197 such that @xmath183 does not belong to a line spanned by any two of the three points ( otherwise all points belong to a union of two lines passing through @xmath183 , which is a reducible conic ) . by the above",
    ", the morphism @xmath198 is a closed immersion ( in fact an isomorphism ) .",
    "let @xmath54 be the maximal number such that there exist @xmath54 points out of @xmath169 lying on a smooth conic .",
    "we can assume without loss of generality that @xmath199 lie on smooth conic .",
    "we consider several cases .",
    "suppose first that @xmath200 .",
    "since , for any @xmath195-element subset @xmath201 , @xmath202 is given by a linear system of conics through @xmath183 , @xmath146 , the geometric fibers of @xmath203 are : ( 1 ) the proper transform @xmath204 of a conic @xmath12 through @xmath199 ( which does not pass through the remaining points ) ; ( 2 ) exceptional divisors @xmath196 , @xmath205 ; ( 3 ) closed points in @xmath206 .",
    "since we already know that @xmath207 is a closed embedding , it suffices to prove that @xmath208 is a closed embedding . for this , consider @xmath209 .",
    "there are two subcases .",
    "if @xmath210 lie on a smooth conic then , since @xmath211 , the linear system of conics through @xmath210 separate points of @xmath204 . if they lie on a reducible conic then @xmath212 must belong to a line connecting a pair of points from @xmath189 , for example @xmath213 and @xmath214 .",
    "then the linear system of lines through @xmath215 separate points of  @xmath204 . in both cases",
    ", @xmath208 is a closed embedding .",
    "note that @xmath216 ( otherwise all points lie on a line through @xmath215 and @xmath213 ) .",
    "we claim that @xmath217 either .",
    "arguing by contradiction , suppose that @xmath218 . then , for any @xmath219 , @xmath183 lies on one of the three lines connecting @xmath215 , @xmath213 , @xmath214 .",
    "moreover , each of these lines must contain at least one of the points @xmath183 , @xmath219 , because otherwise all points lie on the union of two lines .",
    "so suppose that @xmath220 but then @xmath221 lie on a smooth conic .",
    "so the only case left is @xmath222 .",
    "points @xmath223 lie on a union of @xmath224 lines connecting @xmath187 pairwise .",
    "the geometric fibers of @xmath225 are the preimages w.r.t .",
    "the morphism @xmath226 of proper transforms of conics @xmath12 through @xmath187 .",
    "if @xmath12 is a smooth conic then the argument from the @xmath200 case shows that @xmath208 is a closed embedding .",
    "so suppose that @xmath12 is a reducible conic , for example the union of lines @xmath227 and @xmath228 .",
    "note that not all points belong to these two lines , for example suppose @xmath229 belongs to @xmath230 .",
    "then @xmath231 collapses @xmath227 and separates points of @xmath228 .",
    "@xmath232 has an opposite effect .",
    "so @xmath233 separates points of @xmath204 and we are done .    to compute pull - backs of boundary divisors , note that @xmath234 ( set - theoretically ) , and so , for any subset @xmath139 , @xmath235 ( as a cartier divisor ) is a linear combination of proper transforms of lines @xmath236 and exceptional divisors  @xmath196 . in order to compute multiplicity of @xmath235 at one of these divisors @xmath75",
    ", we can argue as follows : suppose @xmath237 is a proper curve intersecting @xmath75 transversally at a point @xmath238 that does not belong to any other boundary component . by the projection formula ,",
    "the multiplicity is equal to the local intersection number of @xmath239 with @xmath172 at @xmath240 .",
    "but this intersection number can be immediately computed from the pullback of the universal family of @xmath40 to @xmath12 . to implement this program , we consider two cases . first , suppose that @xmath241 .",

    "the special fiber has two components , with points marked by @xmath260 one component and points marked by @xmath261 on the other .",
    "this proves the claim in the first case .",

    "we close - up in @xmath258_{(x)}\\to\\spec k[x]_{(x)}$ ] and resolve the special fiber by blowing up points @xmath274 each time there is more than one point with the same slope @xmath275 .",
    "this yields a family of stable curves with a special fiber that contains ( a ) a `` main '' component with points marked by @xmath23 and by @xmath119 each time there is just one point with the slope  @xmath275 ; ( b ) one component ( attached to the main component ) for each @xmath275 that repeats more than once marked by @xmath276 such that @xmath277 .",
    "this proves the claim in the second case .",
    "applying this to @xmath157 gives a covering of @xmath278 by cubic surfaces .",
    "this is related to the fact that @xmath279 is a resolution of singularities of the segre cubic threefold @xmath280 using the formula ( * ? ? ?",
    "* rk.3.1 ) for the pull - back of the hyperplane section of  @xmath281 , it is easy to check that our blow - ups are pull - backs of hyperplane sections of  @xmath281 .",
    "this proves a well - known classical fact that moduli of cubic surfaces are generated by hyperplane sections of @xmath281 ( the cremona hexahedral equations , see @xcite ) .",
    "it deserves mentioning that one of the ( non - general ) blow - ups of @xmath52 in @xmath224 points embedded in @xmath278 this way is the `` keel - vermeire divisor '' , see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 9 ) .",
    "we end this section with the following observation :    [ lines+exc ] in the set - up of theorem [ blowupdescr ] , the numerical classes of proper transforms of lines and exceptional divisors on the blow - up @xmath282 are sums of @xmath0-curves .",
    "we will give an explicit example of how prop .",
    "[ lines+exc ] applies in [ example : sums of f - curves ] .",
    "we argue by induction on @xmath4 .",
    "the proper transform of any line in @xmath282 is linearly equivalent to the sum of exceptional divisors and the proper transform of a line passing through at least two points of @xmath169 , so it is enough to consider these two cases .",
    "case i. the exceptional divisor over @xmath183 maps to a point by the @xmath119-th forgetful map @xmath283 .",
    "any irreducible component @xmath12 of any fiber of the forgetful map is easily seen to be a sum of @xmath0-curves : if the corresponding irreducible component of the @xmath284-pointed stable rational curve has three distinguished points then @xmath12 is an @xmath0-curve .",
    "however , any fiber can be degenerated to a fiber over a @xmath285-dimensional stratum of @xmath286 .",
    "consider the proper transform of a line @xmath287 through at least @xmath288 points of @xmath169 .",
    "the corresponding curve of @xmath40 belongs to the boundary divisor  @xmath172 , so it suffices to show that its projections onto @xmath289 and @xmath290 are sums of @xmath0-curves .",
    "the projection onto @xmath290 can be interpreted as follows : remove points indexed by @xmath139 from @xmath21 and place an extra point @xmath2 at a general point of @xmath287 .",
    "now repeat the construction of theorem  [ blowupdescr ] for this new configuration . by inductive assumption , the proper transform of the line",
    "is the sum of @xmath0-curves on @xmath290 .",
    "the projection onto @xmath289 is immediate : forgetting the extra marking maps the curve to a point of @xmath291 ( given by cross - ratios of @xmath183 , @xmath146 along @xmath287 ) .",
    "so we are done as in case  i.    the next simplest curves in the surfaces @xmath282 are proper transforms of conics through @xmath292 points .",
    "the following is an immediate corollary of thm .",
    "[ blowupdescr ] :    [ class1 ] in the set - up of theorem [ blowupdescr ] , assume the points @xmath293 are in general position and the smooth conic @xmath12 passing through them contains no other points @xmath183 , @xmath294 .",
    "then the proper transform @xmath295 of @xmath12 has the following intersections with boundary divisors : for each line @xmath287 , @xmath296 and for each @xmath178 , @xmath297 other intersection numbers are trivial .",
    "we analyze in detail an example of such a curve in section [ hessesection ] .",
    "let @xmath298 be a quasiprojective morphism of noetherian schemes .",
    "the _ exceptional locus _",
    "@xmath299 is the complement to the union of points in @xmath13 isolated in their fibers . by @xcite .",
    ", @xmath299 is closed .",
    "we use the following observation to construct rigid curves on @xmath3 :    [ rigid ] if a curve @xmath300 is an irreducible component of the exceptional locus of a morphism @xmath301 , with @xmath13 and @xmath20 projective varieties , then @xmath12 is rigid on @xmath13 .",
    "assume @xmath12 is not rigid , i.e. , there is a family @xmath14 over a smooth curve @xmath32 , a map @xmath302 such that @xmath100 is a surface and for some fiber @xmath0 of @xmath148 we have ( set - theretically ) that @xmath303 . since the fibers of @xmath148 are numerically equivalent on @xmath35 , and as @xmath0 is contracted by @xmath304 , it follows that if @xmath305 is some ample divisor on @xmath20 , then every fiber of @xmath148 intersects @xmath306 trivially .",
    "hence , every fiber of @xmath148 is contracted by @xmath29 , i.e. , contained in @xmath299 .",
    "it folows that @xmath307 . as @xmath12 is an irreducible component of @xmath299 ,",
    "this is a contradiction .",
    "one is left to find a morphism @xmath308 as in prop .",
    "[ rigid ] .",
    "the most natural morphisms to consider are products of forgetful morphisms .",
    "we first make the following :    [ hypergraph ] a _ hypergraph _",
    "@xmath309 on the set @xmath310 is a collection of subsets of @xmath311 , called _ hyperedges _ , such that the following conditions are satisfied :    * any subset @xmath312 has at least three elements ; * any @xmath313 is contained in at least two subsets  @xmath312 .",
    "we call a _ hypergraph morphism the product of fogetful maps @xmath314 _    definition [ hypergraph ] generalizes the notion of _ hypertree _ introduced in @xcite ( this construction has first appeared in @xcite )",
    ". essentially , a hypergraph is the simplest structure that allows one to study exceptional loci of products of fogetful maps , by using brill - noether theory of certain reducible curves .",
    "the following are some of the constructions in @xcite in a slightly more general context .",
    "[ valence ] let @xmath309 be a hypergraph .",
    "a curve @xmath315 is called a _ hypergraph curve _ associated to @xmath316 if it has @xmath317 irreducible components @xmath318 , with @xmath319 , marked by @xmath320 and glued at identical markings as a scheme - theoretic push - out : at each singular point @xmath313 , @xmath315 is locally isomorphic to the union of coordinate axes in @xmath321 , where @xmath322 is the valence of @xmath119 , i.e. , the number of subsets @xmath320 that contain  @xmath119 .",
    "we consider @xmath315 as a marked curve ( by indexing its singularities ) .    * identifying @xmath11 with a space of maps @xmath323 . *",
    "if not all the @xmath324 are triples , hypergraph curves will have moduli , namely @xmath325    we observe that @xmath11 can be identified with the variety of morphisms @xmath326 ( modulo the free action of @xmath327 ) , that send singular points @xmath169 of @xmath315 to different points @xmath328 .",
    "( note that the point in @xmath329 corresponding to @xmath315 is determined by the hypergraph morphism @xmath330 . )",
    "this gives a morphism @xmath331 from @xmath11 to the ( relative over @xmath329 ) picard scheme @xmath332 of line bundles on @xmath315 of degree @xmath23 on each irreducible component .",
    "* the exceptional locus of a product of forgetful maps . * as remarked in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* rmk . 2.6 ) most of the constructions in @xcite hold in this more general context . for the reader",
    "s convenience , we recall the main construction .    a linear system on the hypergraph curve @xmath315 is said to be _ admissible _ if it is globally generated and the corresponding morphism @xmath323 sends the singular points of @xmath315 to distinct points .",
    "we define the brill - noether loci @xmath333 and @xmath334 as follows .",
    "the locus @xmath335 parametrizes line bundles @xmath336 such that for each hypergraph curve @xmath315 , the complete linear system @xmath337 is admissible , and we have : @xmath338    the locus @xmath334 parametrizes admissible pencils on @xmath315 such that the corresponding line bundle is in @xmath333 .",

    "recall that any configuration of lines @xmath487 in @xmath52 has an associated _",
    "matroid_. this is a collection of subsets of the set @xmath488 representing linearly independent subsets of the set of linear equations of lines @xmath487 .",
    "we say that a configuration of distinct lines @xmath487 in  @xmath52 is a _ rigid configuration _ if any configuration of lines with the same matroid can be obtained from @xmath487 via an automorphism of @xmath52 .",
    "* the  two conics \" construction .",
    "* let @xmath489 be a rigid configuration of lines in @xmath52 and let @xmath490 be the set of intersection points .",

    "let @xmath2 be the fourth point of intersection of @xmath491 , @xmath492 . for simplicity",

    "[ k1 ] one can see that the intersections with @xmath783 add up .",
    "we have : @xmath784 @xmath785 @xmath786    note that @xmath787 , and thus the usual lower bound for the dimension of the hom scheme @xmath788 at @xmath789 $ ] ( [ lower bound ] ) is @xmath790 .",
    "this shows that @xmath791 satisfies the necessary lower - bound for @xmath12 to be rigid ( although not by a large margin ) .",
    "the same computation also shows that the components of the characteristic @xmath563 fiber are in fact not rigid .",
    "this happens also in our second example ( see rmk .",
    "the calculation above shows that many rigid curves defined using configurations of points often break arithmetically simply because the configuration itself has primes of bad reduction .",
    "here we use the following definition :    let @xmath792 be a finite connected matroid of rank @xmath793 ( see @xcite for the definition of connected matroids ) , let @xmath46 be a domain with the field of fractions @xmath41 , and let @xmath794 be a prime ideal .",
    "we say that @xmath792 has @xmath795 as a prime of bad reduction over @xmath46 if there exists a family of sections @xmath796 such that the matroid of the configuration of points @xmath797 is isomorphic to  @xmath792 , while the matroid of the specialization @xmath798 has rank @xmath793 , is connected , and is a strict subset of @xmath792 ( i.e. ,  the specialization has less linearly independent subsets ) .",
    "a matroid @xmath792 is called _ arithmetically rigid _ if it has no primes of bad reduction .",
    "[ sb ] let @xmath792 be a matroid of rank  @xmath288 . without loss of generality we can assume that @xmath792 is uniform , i.e.  any two points are linearly independent .",
    "of course @xmath792 can not be arithmetically rigid ( unless it has at most three points ) , so let s fix a realization of @xmath792 over a field of fractions  @xmath41 of a dedekind domain @xmath46 , i.e.  a collection of elements @xmath799 .",
    "we can extend them to a collection of sections @xmath800 .",
    "primes of bad reduction correspond to places where two sections intersect",
    ". if there are no places of bad reduction then we can arrange so that @xmath801 , @xmath802 , @xmath803",
    ". then the remaining points @xmath804 form what s known as a _ clique of exceptional units _ : we have @xmath805    how about rank  @xmath563",
    "? we can obtain examples by simply considering rigid matroids which are realizable only in prime characteristic , e.g.  the fano matroid .",
    "so let s impose an extra condition that a matroid is realizable in characteristic  @xmath285 .",
    "it is easy to see using lafforgue s theory @xcite of compact moduli spaces of hyperplane arrangements that if @xmath792 is not rigid then @xmath792 is not arithmetically rigid . in other words ,",
    "if there exists an algebraic curve @xmath32 over an algebraically closed field of characteristic @xmath285 and sections @xmath806 , such that the matroid of @xmath807 is isomorphic to @xmath792 for any @xmath808 and yet configurations @xmath807 and @xmath809 are not projectively equivalent for some @xmath810 then @xmath32 is not proper and one of the infinite points is a prime of bad reduction .",
    "quite surprisingly , we know only two examples of arithmetically rigid matroids of rank  @xmath563 realizable in characteristic  @xmath285 .",
    "one is a uniform matroid ( @xmath195 general points in  @xmath21 ) , which is useless for our purposes .",
    "another is a quite remarkable configuration that represents the golden ratio .",
    "we learned about it from the book @xcite .",
    "let @xmath811 be a root of @xmath812 .",
    "let @xmath813 $ ] and @xmath814 .",
    "consider the following configuration of nine points of @xmath607 ( in coordinates @xmath567 ) : @xmath815 @xmath816 @xmath817    consider the following lines ( see fig .",
    "[ adfgsdfsfb ] ) : @xmath818     and @xmath492),width=480 ]    the only possible non - trivial @xmath819 minors of the @xmath820 matrix of coordinates of points @xmath821 are @xmath822 , @xmath823 , @xmath824 , and @xmath825 .",
    "all these minors are units in @xmath826 $ ] , and therefore the grnbaum configuration has no primes of bad reduction in @xmath826 $ ] .",
    "it is quite easy to check ( see @xcite ) that the grnbaum configuration is rigid and @xmath827 $ ] is its field of definition .",
    "therefore , this matroid is arithmetically rigid .",
    "we find it remarkable that if we pick any smooth conic through five of the nine points , the construction in thm .",

    "now we are going to construct a curve in @xmath837 by applying a `` two conics '' construction .",
    "we will use the configuration in example [ sb ] . up to symmetries , there is only one choice : consider the following two ( smooth ) conics : @xmath838      let @xmath35 be the blow - up of @xmath840 at @xmath2 and let @xmath841 be the exceptional divisor . consider the natural fibration @xmath842 that resolves the projection from @xmath2 .",

    "despite the fact that the grnbaum arrangement is arithmetically rigid , we will prove that @xmath12 breaks in characteristic @xmath292 into several components , each a sum of @xmath0-curves .                  in order to resolve this map ,",
    "one has to blow - up the arithmetic surface @xmath583 several times along the characteristic @xmath292 fiber @xmath853 of @xmath578 ( at @xmath854 ) .",
    "we now outline the strategy .",

    "[ pic_c ] ) .",
    "we let @xmath537 be the resulting arithmetic surface .",
    "we will abuse notations and denote by @xmath586 the proper transform of @xmath586 in @xmath537 .",
    "we construct a family @xmath588 with @xmath26 sections , such that over an open set of the characteristic zero fiber of @xmath602 , this is the universal family .",
    "it is easy to see that along a dense open @xmath589 the sections are disjoint and thus define a map @xmath590 .",
    "moreover , we can enlarge @xmath591 such that that its intersection with each of @xmath0 , @xmath196 is non - empty .",
    "simply blow - up the total space @xmath35 along the sections that become equal over the generic points of these curves ; occasionally one will have to blow - up several times .",
    "this is an easy calculation , which we omit .",
    "the result is a family over @xmath591 of semistable rational curves with twelve disjoint sections . by contracting unstable components in fibers ,",
    "we obtain a family of stable curves over @xmath591 .",
    "the maps @xmath592 , @xmath593 extend uniquely to morphisms @xmath594    just as in section [ break of hypergraph curve ] , from the universal family @xmath595 restricted to @xmath596 , @xmath597 we can determine the classes of the curves @xmath0 , @xmath196 .",

    "we give a different description of the curve @xmath861 . as of now",
    ", the curve @xmath861 is coming from a curve in @xmath829 , and although we know its class , it is less clear how it decomposes as a sum of @xmath0-curves .",
    "we note that the curve @xmath861 is the * irreducible * fiber in characteristic @xmath292 of a different family , this one over @xmath921 .",
    "we will prove that this new family breaks in characteristic @xmath563 into several components , all of which can be written as sums of @xmath0-curves .",

    "the new arithmetic threefold is locally cut by @xmath991 , with exceptional divisor @xmath987 and new coordinate @xmath978 .",

    "along @xmath587 ( @xmath987 ) the sections become : @xmath994"
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> a result of keel and m^c^kernan states that a hypothetical counterexample to the @xmath0-conjecture must come from rigid curves on @xmath1 that intersect the interior . </S>",
    "<S> we exhibit several ways of constructing rigid curves . in all our examples , </S>",
    "<S> a reduction mod @xmath2 argument shows that the classes of the rigid curves that we construct can be decomposed as sums of @xmath0-curves .    </S>",
    "<S> [ section ] [ thm]proposition [ thm]corollary [ thm]lemma [ thm]lemma  definition [ thm]question [ thm]claim    [ thm]definition [ thm]example [ thm]notation [ thm]note [ thm]observation [ thm]remark [ thm]question [ thm ] [ thm ]    # 1    * # 1 *             [ thm ] </S>"
